awd_titl_txt: CIF: Medium: Adaptive Diffusions for Scalable and Robust Learning over Graphs
awd_abstract_narration:
Behind every complex system, be it physical, social, biological, or manmade, lies an intricate network that encodes the interactions between its components. Statistical learning over networks has the potential to unleash one's ability to reason about the behavior of such systems; to understand their innate structure; and, ultimately predict their evolution. In the era of 'data deluge,' fulfilling this promise has not moved closer, as formidable challenges remain. These include making effective predictions while relying on scarce training samples; providing easily explainable outcomes in a transparent way; dealing with unreliable data or malicious attempts to undermine the learning process; as well as managing to handle massive-scale networks that can change over time in a timely and resource-considerate fashion. Aspiring to address such challenges, this project pioneers a scalable, expressive, interpretable, and robust multi-purpose framework for learning over networks. The toolbox to be developed is expected to boost state-of-the-art in data science, network science, graph mining, and big data analytics. It should thus impact and effect technology transfer to a broad range of emerging fields, from computational biology and neuroscience to social-economic networks. On the educational front, the multidisciplinary nature of this research will provide engaging experiences for both undergraduate and graduate students, disseminate research findings, and cross-fertilize ideas from diverse communities.

The overarching approach in this project unifies learning over graphs under a principled framework of random walk based diffusions with the goal of markedly improving learning performance, while also ensuring scalability and reliability. The research consists of three intertwined thrusts dealing with: (T1) Adaptive diffusions for fast and effective learning over networks tuned to the task and the underlying network topology; (T2) Scalable diffusions dealing with massive and challenging networks; and (T3) Robust diffusions capable of learning from untrusted data. The novel approach in T1 capitalizes on the 'landing probabilities' of judiciously constructed random walks, and opens venues leveraging meta-information, as well as nonlinear diffusion models, in order to innovate a gamut of learning tasks over possibly dynamic graphs. The research under T2 aims at massive and challenging graphs where a prohibitively large landing probability space is necessary to ensure high prediction accuracy. Finally, T3 aspires to cope with sophisticated adversaries employing graph structure-aware approaches to infiltrate the network, and investigates lines of defense even in settings where most data are malicious. Analytical and experimental performance evaluation will assess the merits of the novel approaches relative to node embedding and graph convolutional neural network alternatives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The context of this project is scalable and robust learning of processes evolving over graphs that emerge either when complex system components (a.k.a. agents, variables, nodes) are physically interconnected (as e.g., buses in a power grid), or, when these inter-connections capture inter-dependencies among components. The core theme is to leverage inter-dependencies with the main goals to potentially reason about the behavior of such systems; to understand their innate structure; and, ultimately predict their evolution. Scalability is critical for graphs with massive number of nodes (in the order of millions or billions), while nodes can also collect `big data' of possibly high dimensionality. Large-scale graphs may have to deal with large amounts of meta-information; along with sufficient versatility to capture the structure and dynamics of the complex phenomena under study. Robustness and model expressiveness ensure accurate learning, along with transparency interpretability, and resilience against adversarial behavior, and untrusted data. 

The key outcome of this project is a principled framework for scalable and robust learning based on adaptive random walk diffusions over graphs. Specific research outcomes include (i) task-adaptive diffusions for fast and effective learning; (ii) scalable diffusions for massive networks, and robust diffusions that enable learning from untrusted data; (iii) ensemble Gaussian processes for scalable learning and Inference over graphs; (iv) semi-supervised crowdsourcing with sequential and networked data; and (v) pruning graph scattering transforms and graph convolutional networks. 

Major educational/training outcomes in this project, with broader impacts to education and training the next cadre of engineers with AI-driven expertise for inter-connected systems, have included:

E1) Eight (8) Ph.D. and four (4) M.Sc. Theses were supervised; along with eight (8) postdoctoral researchers that were trained on themes related to data science and network science with application to Internet of Things (IoT). Out of these 20 individuals, 10 joined Industry groups (including 3M, Google, Apple, Microsoft, Samsung, Amazon), and 8 joined academic institutions (U. of Georgia, Michigan State U., Washington State U., Hong Kong U. of Science and Technology, and U. of Wisconsin) as assistant professors, or, as postdoctoral researchers (ETH, U. of Texas, Austin).    

E2) Biweekly reading group meetings on advances related to online convex optimization and machine learning for big data analytics with applications to monitoring and resource allocation for  communication, sensing, transportation, and power networks with renewables and electric vehicles. The PI also integrated research with educational modules in Senior Design of Undergraduate Projects, the latest dealing with large-learning models and ChatGPT.

Developing scalable and robust learning approaches for large-scale networks provided the postdocs and graduate students working on this project with deep understanding of graph theory, Gaussian Processes, crowdsourcing approaches, the value of integrating sensing and communication over IoTs, parallel, incremental, active and decentralized learning algorithms, topology identification, interpolation and extrapolation principles over graphs, as well as the fundamentals of statistical inference and Bayesian optimization theory. They further gained hands-on experience with practical models, real data processing, and simulations of the entire protocol stack.

As far as dissemination, the research outcomes have reached communities of interest through research publications, conference and workshop presentations (more than 60 publications over the last 3 years). In addition, the PI delivered keynote addresses, plenaries, tutorials, and invited talks at academic institutions, as well as industrial research labs (more than 50 over the last 3 years).

In most of these addresses, the PI presented advances of learning approaches for large-scale graphs with applications to monitoring and optimizing the design of wireless communication and computing networks, as well as transportation and power grid networks. His talks further covered broader impact themes on machine learning and related statistical tools for network science. 

Besides learning and inference over graphs, other disciplines have been impacted through the analytical, algorithmic, and computational models, tools, and outcomes of this project. These broader disciplines include the fields of optimization, stochastic processes, control systems, machine learning, and statistical signal and image processing. Insights gained from this project’s large-scale network analytics context, will also transfer technology to a broad range of emerging fields, ranging from computational biology and neuroscience to social-economic networks, communication networks, smart grids, smart cities, self-driving vehicles, and IoTs.

Networks play a fundamental role not only in science and economy, but also in our daily life. At a broader scale, the developed technologies will promote societal embracing of the emergent AI-guided network processes including autonomous driving technologies.
